<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 0625/51 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|> October/November 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 842]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 645, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 131, 761, 512]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 530, 532, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 144, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 562, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is clamped in position near to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 181, 626]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 609, 920, 641]]<|/det|>
Write down the scale readings in mm from the metre rule at the top and bottom of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 655, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>top reading = .................................................. mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 686, 920, 703]]<|/det|>
<form>bottom reading = .................................................. mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 701, 920, 719]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 732, 181, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 732, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
Using the two readings, calculate the length \(l_0\) of the spring in mm. Record \(l_0\) in Table 1.1. The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L = 0.00 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 747, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> Suspend a load \(L = 0.20 \text{N}\) from the spring. Record the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 171, 138]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|> Use the equation \(\mathsf{e} = (l - l_0)\) to calculate the extension \(\mathsf{e}\) of the spring. Record the value of \(\mathsf{e}\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 173, 185]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 166, 920, 201]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure using loads \(L = 0.40 \text{N}, L = 0.60 \text{N}, L = 0.80 \text{N}\) and \(L = 1.00 \text{N}\). Record all the readings and results in the Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 214, 541, 231]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 240, 660, 416]]<|/det|>
\(L/\mathrm{N}\)\(l/\mathrm{mm}\)\(e/\mathrm{mm}\)
0.000
0.20
0.40
0.60
0.80
1.00
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 418, 920, 437]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 144, 467]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 448, 576, 467]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(e / \text{mm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(L / \text{N}\) (\(x\)-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 476, 791, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 889, 920, 907]]<|/det|> [4]

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 440, 680, 460]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Reconnect the voltmeter to measure \(V_{\mathrm{XYY}}\) the potential difference across the two resistors X and Y in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 245, 166]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 181, 199]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 240, 799, 261]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 317, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{XYY}}\) the combined resistance of resistors X and Y connected in series, using

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 341, 395, 375]]<|/det|>
the equation \(R_{\mathrm{XY}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{XY}}}{I_{\mathrm{XY}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 368, 431]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 527, 462]]<|/det|>
Connect resistor Z in parallel with resistor X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 508]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 229]]<|/det|>

<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 240, 920, 260]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 262, 395, 298]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 335, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
\[R_{\chi \mathrm{Z}} = \mathrm{..............................................} \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 146, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
A student does this experiment using a set of three identical resistors. Her results show that, within the limits of experimental accuracy, the combined resistance of two identical resistors connected in series is four times the combined resistance of the same two resistors connected in parallel. To test whether her results are true for other values of resistance, she does the same procedure with other sets of three identical resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
Suggest the values of resistance she could use to reach a conclusion during a 1 hour practical lesson.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 596, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 600, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 777, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions. Use the ray-trace sheet supplied, referring to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 147, 776, 617]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 630, 532, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 144, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 661, 166, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>?</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 661, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line MR. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal NL. Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 175, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 724, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(7.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 70^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 771, 175, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 771, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
Draw another line \(7.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle \(\theta = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 801, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 707, 92]]<|/det|>
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 175, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 175, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 149, 920, 200]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 144, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 228, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
Remove the pins and the mirror. Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 720, 293]]<|/det|>
Measure the angle \(\alpha\) between the line and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) below \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[581, 305, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 146, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the centre of the mirror at \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
Place pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{CB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\). Place pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 144, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 626, 571]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 864, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the time taken to heat water in different uninsulated containers. The containers all have the same volume and shape. The water is heated with an electric immersion heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 152]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 322, 181]]<|/det|>
a selection of containers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 285, 196]]<|/det|>
measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 230, 211]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 285, 226]]<|/det|>
supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 420, 242]]<|/det|>
immersion heater with power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 915, 273]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the time taken to heat water in different uninsulated containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 536, 305]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 319, 218, 336]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 140, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 517, 368]]<|/det|>
list any additional apparatus that is required

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 138, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 616, 400]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 136, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 591, 432]]<|/det|>
